awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Comparative Studies of Pleated beta-Sheet and Rippled beta-Sheet Peptide Nanofibrils
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Dr. Bradley L. Nilsson from University of Rochester and Dr. Cristiano Dias from New Jersey Institute of Technology to study the structure and molecular driving forces promoting the assembly of beta-sheet peptides.  Peptides are naturally occurring biological molecules that are found in all living organisms.  In cells, they perform many biological functions, for example acting as hormones.  Beta-sheets are a common structure found in peptide assemblies associated with many human diseases, most notable of which is Alzheimer's disease.  In this work, co-assembly of two peptides that are mirror images of one another is studied using complementary experimental and computational techniques.  These efforts may provide critical insight into the molecular-scale interactions that dictate the assembly of both natural and artificial beta-sheets.  The this research could simplify and guide efforts to rationally design and synthesize the next generation of nanomaterials with peptides that are precisely organized. Outreach activities associated with this work includes an inquiry based mini-course on hydrogels called "To Gel or Not To Gel: The Science of Slime" which is conducted at both institutions.  Additionally, the two research teams host high school interns for six weeks during the summer to provide mentoring and increase interest in scientific research and chemical sciences in general. This work may provide significant societal benefits because it has the potential to provide insight into disease mechanisms that involve beta-sheet self-assembly, such as in Alzheimer's disease and amyloidosis in general.

This research focuses on obtaining fundamental understanding of the structure and molecular forces driving the co-assembly of L- and D-peptides sequences into rippled beta-sheet nanofibrils. This enables the rational design of new peptide sequences that can form rippled beta-sheet nanofibril systems. In the first objective, complementary experimental and theoretical methods are used to characterize the comparative structures of pleated beta-sheet and rippled beta-sheet nanofibrils.  The second objective exploits theory in the computationally-directed assessment and design of rippled beta-sheet nanofibrils from L- and D-peptide sequences. The knowledge obtained may be applicable not only to these specific materials, but also to understanding the role of beta-sheet structures in amyloid self-assembly and in protein folding in general. This work may provide significant societal benefits because it has the potential to provide insight into disease mechanisms that involve beta-sheet self-assembly, such as in Alzheimer's disease and amyloidosis in general.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intelectual Merit: During this project, the Dias lab performed extensive all-atom molecular dynamics simulations to provide a better understanding of the aggregation of short amphipathic beta-sheet peptides. It showed for the first time that unbiased all-atom simulations when performed for a very long time can describe not only the formation of disordered aggregates but also the formation of ordered supramolecular structures, i.e., amyloid fibrils.  Results from these simulations were used to study the role played by hydrophobic and electrostatic interactions in the self-assembly process. Critical insights into the effects of temperature and salts in accelerating the formation of supramolecular structures was also provided. Moreover, a positive correlation was observed between the propensity of a sequence to form fibrils experimentally and in computer simulations. Combined these studies show that all-atom simulations can be utilized not only to explain experimental results but also to make predictions. The assembly of mirror image peptides was also studied showing that depending on the amino acid sequence, L- and D- peptides form rippled beta-sheets where L- and D-peptides alternate along the structure with high propensity.

This project also allowed the Dias lab to investigate at the atomic level how peptides adsorb, aggregate, and damage lipid membranes. It performed the first all-atom simulations in which adsorbed peptides aggregated on the surface of lipid membranes forming beta-sheets that either penetrated the bilayer forming pores or emerged out of it dragging lipids with them. In simulations, adsorption starts with the attraction of positive residues to negative phosphate moieties of lipids followed by the burial on non-polar side chains onto the acyl-tail of lipids. Accordingly, cations which interact with phosphate moieties of lipids rendering zwitterionic membranes positive were shown to inhibit adsorption of amphipathic peptides containing positive lysine residues.

Broad Impact: The collaborative endeavor between the Nilsson (University of Rochester, Department of Chemistry) and Dias (New Jersey Institute of Technology, Department of Physics) labs offered unique training opportunities for graduate students in which they were exposed to experimental and theoretical approaches to study peptide self-assembly. Monthly joint Dias-Nilsson meetings allowed for this type of exposure wherein advanced structural biology techniques were discussed in detail, including solid-state NMR and cryo-electron microscopy coupled with the use of state-of-the-art computational simulations. This unique collaborative environment allowed students to attain fluency in the language of both experimentalists and computational theoreticians. This training environment has produced robust scientists that are able to venture confidently into new interdisciplinary domains. Moreover, undergraduate students from the summer provost program at NJIT also participated in this research project during the Summer and the academic year.

Our team also co-organized the biophysics session of the Mid-Atlantic APS meeting in 2020. Due to COVID, the meeting was help online. This enterprise allowed for additional exposure of students to research in the broad area of biophysics. Graduate students were given the opportunity to present their work as an oral presentation and as a poster. More than 50 individuals attended the biophysics sessions of the Mid-Atlantic APS meeting.

During the course of this project, Dias also develop an android app to teach concepts of physics in a fun manner. The game can be downloaded from the google app store:

https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.diasLabs.NewtonLawsofMotion&hl=en_US&gl=US
